page.lettertext:
fol.129r
Lord Trea
s
May it please yo
r
good L. Wheras an extraordinary
contribution of 90000 pound st
r
ling hath bin required of
e
Provinces,
it falleth out among
e Deputies in
conferring theyr commiss ions,
t
onely
Zeland
ys unwilling
not resolving to contribute but after
e rate of 50000
li
st
r
ling
Howbeyt there is alredy order taken, that
Count Maurice
w
th
certain of
e
States
assembly & of
e
Councel
shall p
nt
ly
into Zeland to
swade
em to concurre w
th
e rest of
e
Provinces. Since
e writing of my last
e 1 of
is
moneth I have bin in communication w
th
divers of
e
State & w
th
Barnevelt
in speciall, who I thought above
e
rest, for displeasing
e Count would not favo
r
that motion
for sending succo
rs
into
France,
but I finde him as forward
as I could desire. Al his dout is of
e meanes to
bring it well to passe w
th
every Provinces contentation
But I told him again & he seemed to assent, that if
the motion be embrased, by those
t
are deputed to
e
Gouverment of
e State, there ys no hardnes in winning
the peoples good liking, This talk I had w
th
him by
way of discourse, & not as charged to
suade yt;
albeyt I could
ceave
t
M
r
Buzenval
had bin w
th
him & told him my designe, as I feare in conversation
w
th
e people of this countrey he doth many more bad
offices, in seconding such humo
rs
, as are not well affected
to her Ma
t
proceeding
. The states have bin in
conference about
e matters of
Britain,
& are half
determined to send unto her
Ma
ty
:
to
e
F
r
King
& to
e
Towne of
Rochel,
t
by common advise some plot may be
devised for freeing that coast in regard of theyr traffique
& for offending the Ennemy, w
ch
is setled there already
but as yet they have not taken any final resolution
differing til Count Maurice be returned out of Zeland
who de
teth to morrow & comes againe as wee suppose
w
th
in these 8 daies at
e furthest. In
e meane season
it is agreed by provision, that for
e assurance of theyr
marchant
, there shalbe 12 ships of warr sent theth
r
out of hand.
fol.129v
In
e matters depending between
e states &
e
ma
[rchants]
adventurers
I have traveled what I can to bring th
[em to]
accord, but heer they stand stifly to
e equity of theyr p
[laccartes]
& have framed an answere to her Ma
t
l
re
s, w
ch
I ha
[ve]
consigned to
e Gouverno
r
of
e Company, from whom h
[er]
Hig
nes
l
re
s were sent unto mee hether, Sins theyr an
[swer]
was made I have moved them earnestly to grow to s
[ome]
accord by communication of Committees to be chosen on bo
[the]
sides, & while they are in conference to let theyr trafficke
have his course taking notes of such tares as shalbe
made on o
r
cloathes for w
ch
they shall have allowance
according to
e order wherin they shall resolve.
How neer they wilbe brought to condescend to this
[demande]
I cannot yet advertise. For they seeme to wholy
[not]
dislike it & yet they caste many dout
to put it of for
[this]
p
nt
. I should but trouble yo
r
L. to discourse
[unto]
yo
u
all that hath passed in o
r
conference, so much as
[is]
requesit I have written to
e Companies at
London
&
Midelborough.
I send yo
r
L. heerw
th
a translation
of
e Answer w
ch
was made unto
e Em
ors Ambass
[ador]
w
ch
I think notw
th
standing shalbee sent to her Ma
[jesty]
by
e States themselves,
& so I take my humble leave
Hage. A
p
7 1592.
